item.title: Arlene Foster announces resignation as DUP leader and NI first minister
item.description: Mrs Foster says she is stepping down as leader on 28 May and as NI first minister at the end of June.

item.title: Electoral Commission to investigate Boris Johnson's Downing Street flat renovations
item.description: The Electoral Commission says there are "reasonable grounds to suspect an offence" may have occurred.

item.title: Ryan Giggs denies assaulting two women
item.description: The Wales manager and Salford City FC co-owner denies three offences against two women in November.

item.title: Wembley park deaths: Two Met PCs charged over crime scene photos
item.description: Sisters Nicole Smallman and Bibaa Henry were found dead in a park in Wembley last June.

item.title: Fishmongers' Hall: Killer's family 'truly sorry' about attack
item.description: The brother of terrorist Usman Khan apologises to the families of Jack Merritt and Saskia Jones.

item.title: Britney Spears asks to address court over conservatorship case
item.description: A judge grants request for the singer to speak in hearing about her long-running guardianship case.

item.title: Covid: One dose of vaccine halves transmission - study
item.description: People who get coronavirus after their first jab are up to 49% less likely to pass it on, research suggests.

item.title: Covid: Spain hopes for tourists as EU votes on digital passports
item.description: Spain says it hopes to open up to overseas travellers in June with a pilot test next month.

item.title: Brexit: European Parliament backs UK trade deal
item.description: Euro MPs back the EU-UK trade deal by 660 votes to 5 despite rows over fishing and Northern Ireland.

item.title: Reckitt: More sex, fewer colds drive sales at Durex maker
item.description: Consumer goods giant Reckitt saw a rise in sales of its condoms in countries where lockdowns eased.

item.title: Hamilton is latest musical to announce West End return
item.description: The hit show is planning to be back on stage in London in August, as theatres aim to open up again.

item.title: Family-meal image wins international food photo contest
item.description: A photo of a family preparing a meal in China wins Pink Lady Food Photographer of the Year 2021.

item.title: Five Boris Johnson claims fact-checked
item.description: Investigating claims about flat renovations, vaccines and misleading statements.

item.title: Children of the 90s study: 'I feel privileged to be part of it'
item.description: In 1991, Bristol University began tracking 14,000 pregnant women - and it's still studying their children.

item.title: Birds of Oz: The charming natives that found TikTok fame
item.description: A colourful set of Australian birds has attracted a surprise global following on social media.

item.title: EastEnders actress Lacey Turner calls for better miscarriage support
item.description: Lacey Turner has has two miscarriages and believes the current system needs reforming.

item.title: Why a US photographer says 'sorry for the war'
item.description: Peter van Agtmael chronicles the perception of the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq and their realities.

item.title: Lotus to launch last pure petrol sports car
item.description: The Emira will be the carmaker's last conventionally powered model, as it prepares for an all-electric future.

item.title: Pink Supermoon seen around the world
item.description: Stargazers were treated to the fourth full Moon of 2021 on Monday night.

item.title: Arlene Foster: From trailblazing leader to party civil war
item.description: BBC News NI looks back at the career of first minister of Northern Ireland, Arlene Foster.

item.title: Covid-19: UK Indians rally to help during Covid crisis
item.description: British Indians are fundraising for oxygen equipment as family abroad face record Covid infections.

item.title: CEO Secrets: Why crying can help you succeed in business
item.description: Tina Chen explains how it can be tough starting a business on your own in a new country.

item.title: Downing Street flat: What are the rules about political donations?
item.description: Boris Johnson is under mounting pressure over the funding of his Downing Street flat renovations.

item.title: Hartlepool by-election: Old certainties no longer apply
item.description: The traditional political rule about governments losing by-elections do not seem to count for much now.

item.title: Saving cash: A customer said we'd changed her life
item.description: Eight locations across the UK are testing ideas aimed at ensuring future access to cash for those who need it.

item.title: Emilia Clarke on the book that helped her to grieve for her dad
item.description: Jenny Diski's writing was "tonic for the soul" for the Game of Thrones star after her father died.

item.title: Dog theft: Simple tips to stop your puppy being pinched
item.description: With dog thefts on the rise, here are some tips on how you can keep your dog as safe as possible.

item.title: Kenyans bitter over al-Qaeda US embassy compensation snub
item.description: Kenyan victims of 1998 US embassy bombing lament exclusion from $335m compensation deal.

item.title: Kuwait: Murder spurs demands for greater safety for women
item.description: The killing by the woman's alleged harasser fuels outrage over women's safety in the Gulf state.

item.title: Mon Laferte: The Chilean pop sensation challenging repression
item.description: Musician Mon Laferte is releasing her first album since speaking out about the country's protests.

item.title: India Covid: The messages deciding between life and death
item.description: Avani Singh was one of thousands of Indians who turned to social media to get help for her family.

item.title: Wales back North out of Lions tour with knee injury
item.description: Wales back George North is ruled out of the British and Irish Lions tour of South Africa because of a serious knee injury.

item.title: World Snooker Championship: Mark Selby and Kyren Wilson advance to semi-finals
item.description: Mark Selby and Kyren Wilson move into the semi-finals of the World Championship with commanding victories over Mark Williams and Neil Robertson.

item.title: Marcelo doubt for Real against Chelsea after polling duty call in Madrid
item.description: Real Madrid's Marcelo may miss their Champions League semi-final second leg at Chelsea because of polling station during local elections.

item.title: 'It's for gymnasts who don't feel safe' - Voss on full-body suits
item.description: Gymnast Sarah Voss says she wants to be a "role model for young gymnasts who don't feel very safe" after competing in a full-body suit.

item.title: Why Sterling is man for Man Cityâ€™s big moment against PSG - Micah Richards analysis
item.description: BBC pundit Micah Richards says Manchester City forward Raheem Sterling has returned to form at exactly the right time before their Champions League semi-final against Paris St-Germain.

item.title: Why India's Covid crisis matters to the whole world
item.description: The situation in India is a bleak reminder that none of us will be safe until everyone is safe.

item.title: India's Covid crisis: 'I lost my unborn child and wife on the same day'
item.description: As India battles a fierce Covid second wave, two people who are grieving share their stories.

item.title: India Covid: Trying to revive Covid patients in a Delhi hospital
item.description: What it's like working in an emergency room in India, as its devastating second Covid wave continues.

item.title: Covid-19 in India: Cases, deaths and oxygen supply
item.description: Maps, charts and graphics explaining what is happening and what the authorities are doing about it.

item.title: India coronavirus: Can it make enough vaccines to meet demand?
item.description: India is facing a surge in Covid cases while attempting to ramp up its own vaccine programme.

item.title: Covid: When, where and how can I go on holiday in the UK?
item.description: The rules on where you can holiday in the UK are being relaxed - but some restrictions remain.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's happening with pools, haircuts and gyms?
item.description: Lockdown has been eased further - but what does it mean for hairdressers, pools and gyms?

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk on transport?
item.description: As UK coronavirus restrictions continue to be relaxed, public transport could become much busier.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People 42 or over in England are now being offered a Covid vaccine as the rollout continues.

item.title: Covid: Restaurants and pubs are reopening, but what are the rules?
item.description: Pubs, cafes and restaurants are now allowed to reopen indoors and outdoors in Scotland - and outdoors in Wales.

item.title: Have lockdowns affected my child's physical and mental health?
item.description: Should parents of under-fives worry about Covid restrictions harming their child's development?

item.title: Covid: What is the rule of six and what are the social distancing rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules have been eased further across the UK - more people can meet up outside.

item.title: Lateral-flow tests: What are the risks and benefits?
item.description: What are the risks and benefits from using wide-scale lateral-flow tests?

item.title: Rare blood clots - what you need to know
item.description: We take a look at why these unusual clots happen and when they occur.

item.title: India Covid: Patients dying without oxygen amid Delhi surge
item.description: Delhi hospitals run out of beds and oxygen as families struggle to save their loved ones.
